{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox writer | image = | caption = Joe Lipari by TONE | name = Joe Lipari | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|10|5}} | birth_place = [[Passaic]], [[New Jersey]], US | education = | occupation = Writer, comedian, filmmaker | nationality = Italian American | genre = Comedy, horror, drama | period = | notableworks = Something Awesome, ''Dream Job'', [[Fangoria Radio]] | spouse = | partner = | awards = | website = {{URL|http://www.JoeLipari.com}} | portaldisp = }} '''Joe Lipari''', also known as J.R. Lipari, (born October 5, 1979) is an American writer, marketer, comedian and artist.
== Personal life == Born in [[Passaic, New Jersey]], the first of three children, Lipari is a distant relative of [[Fred Allen]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
After high school Lipari joined The [[United States Army]] and became a member of the [[3rd Infantry Division (United States)|3rd Infantry Division]]. An expert [[marksman]], Lipari worked as a military advisor to defense contractors like [[Honeywell]]. As an advisor, Lipari was a key member of the development of the [[Land Warrior]] system.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} After two years in the military Lipari blew out his knee and is now a [[Disabled American Veterans|Disabled Veteran]].
Prior to leaving the Army, Lipari attended classes at [[Troy State University]], [[Bergen Community College|Bergen County Community College]], [[Santa Monica College]], [[Connecticut School of Broadcasting|The Connecticut School of Broadcasting]], [[New York Film Academy|The New York Film Academy]], The [[School of Visual Arts]] and received camera training at [[Panavision]] in Hollywood. It was at Bergen County Community College that Lipari's speech teacher gave him a push to try stand-up comedy. In 2017 Lipariearned a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] focused in Advertising, Design & Visual Storytelling, with honors, at SVA; where he studied with Richard Wilde, [[James C. Strouse]], Nick Paparone, [[Louise Fili]], Kevin O'Callaghan, [[Gail Anderson (graphic designer)]] and [[Milton Glaser]].
An avid yoga enthusiast, Lipari practices frequently with close friend [[Tara Stiles]]. Lipari is a graduate of the [[Strala Yoga]] one-month intensive teacher training program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Strala Yoga|url=http://stralayoga.com/guides/joe-lipari/|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> Lipari teaches yoga sporadically, occasionally substitute teaching for friends who lead yoga classes in New York City.
[[File:Joe Lipari Newport Beach.jpg|thumb|Lipari shot during "[[Golden hour (photography)|Magic Hour]]" at [[Newport Beach]], California]] [[File:Dream Job Forbidden Planet.jpg|thumb|[[Dave Hill (comedian)|Dave Hill]], [[TONE]], Joe Lipari and [[Renan Kanbay]] on location at [[Forbidden Planet (bookstore)|Forbidden Planet]] (2011)]]
== Career ==
In February 2003 Lipari first tried stand-up at [[Carolines on Broadway|Caroline's on Broadway]], in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Site|url=http://www.joelipari.com/?page_id=2|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref>
Lipari received training as a [[comedy writer]] and [[improvisor]] at [[The People's Improv Theater]] in New York City; where he worked with [[Ali Reza Farahnakian|Ali Farahnakian]], [[Kristen Schaal]], [[Kurt Braunohler]] and [[Ellie Kemper]].
From April 2004 through June 2007 Lipari worked as a writer/producer for ''[[Starlog]]'' and ''[[Fangoria]]'' and as the on-air producer for [[Fangoria Radio]] (hosted by [[Dee Snider]] and [[Debbie Rochon]]) on [[Sirius Satellite Radio]].<ref>{{cite web|title=IMDB "Other Works"|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3565825/otherworks}}</ref> After leaving ''Fangoria'' Lipari worked as a freelance writer and producer for various clients and as a [[production assistant]]/[[camera operator]] for [[MTV]]'s hit reality shows ''[[The Hills (TV series)|The Hills]]'' and ''[[The City (MTV series)|The City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Filmography|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3565825/|work=IMDB "filmography"}}</ref> [[File:Diamond-cutter1.jpg|thumb|Lipari receives a [[Diamond Cutter]] from [[Diamond Dallas Page]] at [[Sirius Radio]] (2007)]]
In 2005 Lipari started performing at [[Gotham Comedy Club]], where he began working with [[Eddie Brill]], [[Greg Giraldo]], [[Cooper, Rego]], [[Jim Mendrinos]], [[Amy Schumer]], and [[Jessica Kirson]].
In 2009 and 2010, Lipari and [[Scout Durwood]] hosted ''Something Awesome'', a live show that was "Part stand-up, part [[burlesque]] and all awesome". The show was a late night Friday night show at [[Comix NY|Comix Comedy Club]] in New York City's [[Meat Packing District]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Site|url=http://www.joelipari.com/?p=1463|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref> After a sold out ''Something Awesome'' [[Greg Giraldo]] told Lipari that he thought the story Lipari told on stage would make a fun movie idea and Lipari should write a script. After Giraldo's advice Lipari wrote a script for the short film that would later be called ''Dream Job.''{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
After doing stand-up about becoming a [[yoga]] teacher at New York City's [[Gotham Comedy Club]], Lipari was approached by a casting associate who was looking for a "sarcastic yogi". After a few questions Lipari was cast in ''[[Eat, Pray, Love]]'', starring [[Julia Roberts]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Times of India|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-09-19/news-interviews/28067400_1_yoga-class-julia-roberts-tara-stiles | work=The Times of India | date=September 19, 2009}}</ref>
Lipari wrote, produced and directed the short film, ''Dream Job'',<ref>{{cite web|title=IMDB|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1956481/|work=IMDB}}</ref> as a thesis project for The [[New York Film Academy]]'s one-year filmmaking program. ''Dream Job'' was an official selection at various film festivals (including The [[New York Friars' Club|Friars Club]] Comedy Film Festival,<ref>{{cite web|title=Festival Genius|url=http://friarsclub.festivalgenius.com/2012/films/dreamjob_joelipari_friarsclub2012}}</ref> [[Quirkfest]]<ref>{{cite web|title=QuirkFest Scheduel|url=http://www.quirkfest.com/Schedule.html}}</ref> and [[Hollywood Shorts]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Hollywood Shorts : 11/18/12|url=http://blog.hollywoodshorts.com/2012/11/short-film-program-2/}}</ref>) and was runner-up for an [[Audience Award]] at the 16th annual [[PictureStart Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|title=NYC PictureStart Film Festival awards and photos|url=http://us4.campaign-archive2.com/?u=c622e27a983bd8aeaa66c524b&id=7cf310c9fc&e=4fd6ba3a07|access-date=2018-07-12|via=campaign-archive2.com|publisher=[[PictureStart Film Festival]]}}</ref>
In 2012, Lipari began teaching a [[DIY]] : No Budget Filmmaking workshop at the [[Improv Olympic]] in Hollywood ([[I.O. West]]) and [[The People's Improv Theater]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|title=IO West Official Site|url=http://ioimprov.com/west/performers/instructors#instructor_916|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The PIT NYC|url=http://thepit-nyc.com/section/no-budget-filmmaking/|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref> In the 7-week workshop, Lipari helps a small group of filmmakers write manageable scripts and produce 5- to 10-minute short films on limited time, money and resources.
In the summer of 2012 Lipari returned to the New York to work at [[Motive NYC]] with long-time collaborator [[Chris Valentino]]. While at Motive Lipari oversaw the production of the [[McDonald's]]/[[Coca-Cola]] Fountain Joy app as well as various motion graphics projects for TV broadcast; including [[House Hunters International]]. Lipari left Motive after it joined the [[Lively Group]] to work on various TV and film productions including ''[[30 for 30]]'' on [[ESPN]] and ''[[The Amazing Spider-Man 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title= IMDB |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3565825/}}</ref>
In 2014 Lipari accepted a position as VP of PR & Marketing for Serious Audio Video, an industry leading Smart Home and Integrated Systems firm in Union City, NJ.<ref>{{cite web|title=Industry Leader|url=http://www.commercialintegrator.com/article/top_5_retail_market_integrators_of_2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Industry Leader|url=http://www.commercialintegrator.com/article/top_5_bar_and_restaurant_market_integrators_of_2016}}</ref><ref name="Serious Audio Video">{{cite web|title=The Team|url=http://www.seriousaudiovideo.com/the-team/}}</ref> ''Commercial Integrator Magazine'' selected Lipari as one of the Top Industry Influencers Under 40 in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Industry Leader|url=http://www.commercialintegrator.com/article/40_ci_influencers_under_40_class_of_2016}}</ref>
New Year's Weekend 2015, Lipari took part in the [[Guinness World Records]] record breaking 60-hour Variety Show at [[New York City]]'s [[Metropolitan Room]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Theater Mania |url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/the-metropolitan-room-breaks-world-record-for-long_71192.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Metropolitan Room |url=http://metropolitanroom.com/event.cfm?cart&id=179517}}</ref> [[Image:At Caroline's.jpg|thumb|Lipari and [[Chuck Nice]] on stage at [[Caroline's on Broadway]] in New York City (2004)]]
In 2017 Lipari worked on season 2 of [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]]/[[Netflix]] show ''[[Jessica Jones (TV series)|Jessica Jones]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=IMDB |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3565825/}}</ref> and accepted a position as a Senior Creative Manager for the [[Brooklyn Nets]]' front office in the Global Marketing division.<ref>{{cite web|title=BK Nets Website |url=http://www.nba.com/nets/brooklyn/front_office_brooklyn}}</ref>{{fv|date=July 2018}}
When his schedule permits, Lipari is a regular at top comedy venues including [[The Improv]],<ref>{{cite web|title= The Improv Official Site|url=http://improv.com/comedian.cfm?id=1559|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref> The [[Jon Lovitz]] Comedy Club,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Jon Lovitz Club Official|url=http://thejonlovitzcomedyclub.com/comedian.cfm?id=1559|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref> [[The Ice House (comedy club)|The Ice House]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ice House |url=http://icehousecomedy.com/comedian.cfm?id=1559}}</ref> [[Gotham Comedy Club]], [[Carolines on Broadway]], [[The People's Improv Theater]] and [[I.O. West]]<ref>{{cite web|title=IO West: Performers |url=http://ioimprov.com/west/performers/joe-lipari|dead-url=yes}}{{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref>
== Terrorism == After being frustrated with the customer service at an [[Apple Store]], in September 2009, Lipari jokingly paraphrased a quote from the book/movie [[Fight Club (film)|''Fight Club'']], which referred to use of firearms, on his Facebook page. In under 2 hours, [[NYPD]] [[SWAT]] arrived at his door and, after searching his apartment, they brought Lipari to the station to be questioned by [[Homeland Security]].<ref name=bencalhoun />
Lipari spent a year in court clearing his name of all charges, even turning down multiple plea bargains. Eventually The City of New York dropped all charges, including making terrorist threats and disorderly conduct. Since then Lipari has received offers from lawyers pushing him to sue New York City for wrongful imprisonment, but he has no plans to sue. When Emily Epstein from [[Metro New York]] pressed him as to why, he replied "I'd rather be rich on my own accord, not by suing the people who are just trying to keep us safe."<ref name=metrony>{{cite web|title=Joe Lipari: The poster child for Internet stupidity?|url=http://www.metro.us/newyork/local/article/902097--joe-lipari-the-poster-child-for-internet-stupidity|first1=Emily Anne|last1=Epstein|dead-url=yes|archive-url=http://archive.li/hIFR#selection-1211.0-1211.52|archive-date=2012-08-04|date=2011-06-27|publisher=[[Metro New York]]}}</ref>
His story was first covered by ''[[This American Life]]''<ref name=bencalhoun>{{cite web|last=Calhoun|first=Ben|title=Right to Remain Silent|url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/414/right-to-remain-silent?act=1|publisher=This American Life|accessdate=September 10, 2010}}</ref> in September 2010. It was also a cover story for ''[[Metro New York]]''<ref name=metrony/> and featured in Britain's daily newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=Maev|title=Twitter Joke Trial...|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/24/twitter-joke-trial-bomb-threat|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=September 24, 2010|location=London|date=September 24, 2010}}</ref> Lipari appears in the documentary ''[[Terms and Conditions May Apply]]'' alongside [[Moby]], [[Orson Scott Card]] and an ambush of [[Mark Zuckerberg]], the documentary premiered at [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]. Lipari also appeared w/ [[John Stossel]] on the [[Fox News]] special "Policing America".<ref name=FoxNews>{{cite web|title=Fox News|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2014/07/23/conservatives-libertarians-and-liberals-should-all-worry-about-militarization.html}}</ref>
In light of the [[NSA]]/[[Edward Snowden]] controversy, Lipari created the [[White House]] [[petition]] to designate June 9 "Everyone Is a Suspect" Day.<ref name=WhiteHouse.Org>{{cite web|title=Petition|url=http://wh.gov/l3lxJ}}</ref> [[File:Joe Lipari Herb Trimpe NYCBM.jpg|thumb|Joe Lipari & [[Herb Trimpe]] at NYCBM 2014]]
